He had accepted the position of a charioteer for His devotee, His supreme position was not challenged. In all circumstances, He is the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
The Lord is always seeking an opportunity to render some service to the devotee.
He takes greater pleasure in His pure devotee's assuming the advantageous position of ordering Him than He does in being the giver of orders.
When He finds that a pure devotee is ordering Him, He obtains transcendental pleasure, although He is the infallible master of all circumstances.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.23

statements.statement: Arjuna was quite confident of victory because Kṛṣṇa was sitting by his side.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.24

statements.statement: Arjuna conquered both sleep and ignorance because of his friendship with Kṛṣṇa.

A great devotee of Kṛṣṇa could not forget Kṛṣṇa even for a moment, because that is the nature of a devotee. Either in waking or in sleep, a devotee of the Lord can never be free from thinking of His name, form, quality, and pastimes.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.25

statements.statement: Hṛṣīkeśa, the Lord, said, 'Just behold, Pārtha, all the Kurus who are assembled here.'
The mind of Arjuna was thus predicated by the Lord in friendly joking.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.30

statements.statement: I am forgetting myself, and my mind is reeling.
Arjuna is supposed to show disregard for self-interest by submission to the will of Kṛṣṇa, who is everyone's real self-interest.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.31

statements.statement: Two kinds of men, namely the kṣatriya who dies directly in front of the battlefield under Kṛṣṇa's personal orders and the person in the renounced order of life who is absolutely devoted to spiritual culture, are eligible to enter into the sun-globe, which is so powerful and dazzling.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 1.32-35

statements.statement: I am not prepared to fight.
Although Govinda is not meant for satisfying our senses, if we try to satisfy the senses of Govinda then automatically our own senses are satisfied.
The Lord will satisfy the senses of the living entities as much as they deserve, but not to the extent that they may covet.
Arjuna fears that all his relatives and friends will be killed in the battlefield, and he will be unable to share his opulence after victory. This is a typical calculation of material life.
Arjuna did not know that Kṛṣṇa had already killed them before their coming into the battlefield and that he was only to become an instrument for Kṛṣṇa.
The Lord can excuse a person on His own account, but He excuses no one who has done harm to His devotees.
Kṛṣṇa never brings misfortune to anyone, to say nothing of His devotees.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.1

statements.statement: Material compassion, lamentation and tears are all signs of ignorance of the real self.
This realization is made possible by working with the fruitive being situated in the fixed conception of the real self.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.5

statements.statement: According to scriptural codes, a teacher who engages in an abominable action and has lost his sense of discrimination is fit to be abandoned.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.7

statements.statement: By nature's own way the complete system of material activities is a source of perplexity for everyone.

All Vedic literatures advise us to approach a bona fide spiritual master to get free from the perplexities of life which happen without our desire. They are like a forest fire that somehow blazes without being set by anyone.
The krpanas, or miserly persons, waste their time in being overly affectionate for family, society, country, etc., in the material conception of life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.8

statements.statement: Although Arjuna was putting forward so many arguments based on knowledge of the principles of religion and moral codes.
Academic knowledge, scholarship, high position, etc., are all useless in solving the problems of life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.9

statements.statement: Although Arjuna was for the time being overwhelmed with false grief due to family affection, he surrendered unto Krsna, the supreme spiritual master, as a disciple.

This indicated that he would soon be free from the false lamentation resulting from family affection and would be enlightened with perfect knowledge of self-realization, or Krsna consciousness, and would then surely fight.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.10

statements.statement: It appears that the talk between the master and the disciple was openly exchanged in the presence of both armies so that all were benefitted.
So the talks of Bhagavad-gītā are not for any particular person, society, or community, but they are for all, and friends or enemies are equally entitled to hear them.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.11

statements.statement: It will be explained in later chapters, it will be clear that knowledge means to know matter and spirit and the controller of both.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.12

statements.statement: When one accepts Kṛṣṇa as an ordinary man, the Gītā loses all importance.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.13

statements.statement: The Māyāvādī theory of oneness of the spirit soul cannot be entertained on the ground that spirit soul cannot be cut into pieces as a fragmental portion.
The fragmental portions of the Supreme exist eternally (sanātana) and are called kṣara; they have a tendency to fall down into material nature.
Even after liberation, the individual soul remains the same fragmental; but lives an eternal life in bliss and knowledge with the Personality of Godhead.
The stars can be compared to the living entities and the sun or the moon to the Supreme Lord.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.14

statements.statement: In the proper discharge of duty, one has to learn to tolerate nonpermanent appearances and disappearances of happiness and distress.

ref: Translation Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.15

statements.statement: The person who is not disturbed in happiness and distress and is steady in both is certainly eligible for liberation.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.15

statements.statement: Anyone who is steady in his determination for the advanced stage of spiritual realization and can equally tolerate the onslaughts of distress and happiness is certainly a person eligible for liberation.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.16

statements.statement: In the Viṣṇu Purāṇa it is stated that Viṣṇu and His abodes all have self-illuminated spiritual existence.
One can understand the nature of the Supreme by thorough study of oneself, recognizing the part-whole relationship.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.17

statements.statement: The individual particle of spirit soul is a spiritual atom smaller than material atoms and such atoms are innumerable.
According to the Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad, this atomic soul is situated in the heart of every living entity.
The atomic soul is definitely there in the heart along with the Supersoul; bodily energies emanate from this part of the body.
Medical science admits that the heart is the seat of all energies of the body.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.20

statements.statement: One who has become free from all material desires and lamentations can, by the grace of the Supreme, understand the glories of the soul.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.22

statements.statement: From old age, the change is transferred to another body.
Transference of the atomic individual soul to another body is made possible by the grace of the Supersoul.
Arjuna has now turned his face towards his eternal friend, Kṛṣṇa, and is understanding the Bhagavad-gītā from Him.
Arjuna can understand the supreme glories of the Lord and be free from lamentation.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.25

statements.statement: No one can establish his existence experimentally beyond the proof of śruti or Vedic wisdom.
The infinitesimal soul, being unchangeable, can never become equal to the infinite soul, or the Supreme Personality of Godhead.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.47

statements.statement: One has a right to perform prescribed duties, but should not be attached to the results.
One should not be attached to not doing one’s duty, even if there is no desire for the result.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.48

statements.statement: Performing one’s duty with equipoise, without getting entangled in success or failure, is called yoga.
Yoga is skill in action.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.49

statements.statement: Action motivated by desire is far inferior to action performed in yoga consciousness.
Seek refuge in yoga, because those who work for fruitive results are misers.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.50

statements.statement: By engaging in devotional service or karma-yoga, one becomes free from the bonds of good and bad results.
Karma-yoga is therefore the art of all work.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.51

statements.statement: Wise men, by renouncing the fruits of action, are freed from the bondage of birth and death and attain the blissful state beyond miseries.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.52

statements.statement: When one’s intelligence is no longer bewildered by conflicting scriptural injunctions, he becomes fixed in trance.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.55

statements.statement: When a person gives up all desires for sense gratification, arising from mental concoction, he is said to be situated in self-realization.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.57

statements.statement: A person not disturbed by happiness and distress and who is steady in both is certainly eligible for liberation.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.58

statements.statement: One who is able to withdraw the senses from their objects, as the tortoise draws its limbs within the shell, is firmly fixed in perfect consciousness.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.61

statements.statement: Keeping the senses always in check by engaging in devotional service to the Lord, the practitioner attains complete steadiness of mind.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.63

statements.statement: From anger, complete delusion arises, leading to bewilderment of memory, loss of intelligence, and finally total ruin.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.64

statements.statement: One who can control his senses by regulative principles and remains free from attachment and aversion can attain the mercy of the Lord.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.66

statements.statement: Without Krishna consciousness, one can have neither a controlled mind nor steady intelligence; without these, there is no possibility of peace or happiness.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.70

statements.statement: As long as one has the material body, the demands of the body for sense gratification will continue. The devotee, however, is not disturbed by such desires because of his fullness. A Krsna conscious man is not in need of anything because the Lord fulfills all his material necessities. Therefore he is like the ocean—always full in himself.
The proof of a Krsna conscious man - one who has lost all inclinations for material sense gratification, although the desires are present.
One who fulfills desires even up to the limit of liberation, what to speak of material success, never attains peace.

ref: Translation Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 2.71

statements.statement: A person who has given up all desires for sense gratification, who lives free from desires, who has given up all sense of proprietorship and is devoid of false ego - he alone can attain real peace.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.1

statements.statement: Arjuna wanted to skillfully avoid the fighting by using Kṛṣṇa consciousness as an excuse.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.3

statements.statement: The path of Kṛṣṇa consciousness is better because it does not depend on purifying the senses by a philosophical process; it is itself the purifying process, simultaneously easy and sublime.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.4

statements.statement: Simply adopting sannyāsa without purification of the heart is a disturbance to the social order; Lord Kṛṣṇa does not approve this.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.5

statements.statement: Even imperfect practice of Kṛṣṇa consciousness is better than perfect adherence to purificatory processes without Kṛṣṇa consciousness; sannyāsa and other purifications are meant to lead to Kṛṣṇa consciousness.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.6

statements.statement: One who makes a show of yogi while seeking sense gratification is the greatest cheater; his knowledge is taken away by the Lord’s illusory energy.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.8

statements.statement: Work should not be abandoned without purifying materialistic propensities; sense gratification must be transcended.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.9

statements.statement: Nothing should be done for sense gratification; everything should be performed for the satisfaction of Kṛṣṇa.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.11

statements.statement: Sanctified food purifies existence, enhances memory, leads to liberation, and culminates in Kṛṣṇa consciousness, the great need of society.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.12

statements.statement: For those who cannot understand Kṛṣṇa, sacrifice to the demigods is recommended.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.16

statements.statement: Those who are not Kṛṣṇa conscious are certainly engaged in sensory consciousness.
The prosperity of the world depends not on our own efforts but on the background arrangement of the Supreme Lord, directly carried out by the demigods.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.17

statements.statement: A person who is fully Kṛṣṇa conscious and satisfied by his acts has no duty to perform.
By clearing of consciousness, one becomes fully confident of his eternal relationship with the Supreme.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.19

statements.statement: A person acting for Kṛṣṇa without attachment to results is certainly progressing toward the supreme goal of life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.20

statements.statement: Although a Kṛṣṇa conscious person may have no personal interest in the world, he still works to teach others how to live properly.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.22

statements.statement: Although He is above all regulations, the Lord does not do anything against revealed scriptures.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.24

statements.statement: Pseudo-devotees should not imitate Kṛṣṇa's pastimes like rāsa-līlā without qualification; one should simply follow His instructions.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.26

statements.statement: A realized soul in Kṛṣṇa consciousness should not disturb others but teach how to dedicate the results of work to Kṛṣṇa.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.27

statements.statement: The person in false ego wrongly takes all credit for activities, showing nescience.
Misuse of the senses for sense gratification bewilders one with false ego, causing forgetfulness of the eternal relationship with Kṛṣṇa.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.29

statements.statement: Devotees are more kind than even the Lord because they understand His ultimate purpose.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.30

statements.statement: One must sacrifice everything for the goodwill of the Supreme Lord.
The Supreme Lord is the soul of all souls.
Nirāśīḥ means one must act on the master's order without expecting fruitive results.
Everything belongs to the Supreme Lord; nothing belongs to any individual.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.31

statements.statement: In the beginning of Kṛṣṇa consciousness, even imperfect adherence is beneficial if performed sincerely and without resentment.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.33

statements.statement: Unless one is situated on the transcendental platform of Kṛṣṇa consciousness, he cannot escape the influence of material nature.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.34

statements.statement: Material necessities are permitted under rules, but one should remain unattached to them.
Attachment even to regulated sense enjoyment should be avoided; real purpose is to become situated in Kṛṣṇa consciousness.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.35

statements.statement: Prescribed duties should match one's nature; one should not imitate others' duties.
When transcendental, one can perform anything under spiritual master's direction.
On the transcendental platform, material distinctions no longer apply.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.36

statements.statement: Contact with material nature leads one to sinful acts, sometimes even against one's will.
Sinful actions are caused not by the Supersoul but by another cause.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 3.37

statements.statement: Unsatisfied lust turns into wrath; wrath leads to illusion, perpetuating material existence.
Lust alone entangles the pure living entity in the material world.
The Supreme Lord expanded Himself for spiritual bliss; living entities are part of that bliss.
When baffled by lust, living entities inquire into their true spiritual position.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.10

statements.statement: The body is perishable, full of ignorance and completely miserable, people in general keep same bodily idea in mind when they are informed of the personal form of the Lord. For such materialistic men, the form of the gigantic material manifestation is supreme. Consequently they consider the Supreme to be impersonal. So they naturally prefer a kind of merging into impersonal void.

Being embarrassed by so many theories and by contradictions of various types of philosophical speculation, one become disgusted or angry and foolishly conclude that there is no supreme cause and that everything is ultimately void. Such people are in a diseased condition of life.

Some of them disbelieve in everything, being angry at all sorts of spiritual speculation out of hopelessness. This last class of men take to the shelter of some kind of intoxication, and their affective hallucinations are sometimes accepted as spiritual vision.

One has to get rid of all three stages of attachment to the material world: negligence of spiritual life, fear of a spiritual personal identity, and the conception of void that underlies the frustration of life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.11

statements.statement: Krşņa rewards all the devotees equally, according to their different intensities of love for Him. In the material world, the same reciprocations of feelings are there, and they are equally exchanged by the Lord with the different types of worshipers.

For those who are fruitive workers, the Lord awards the desired results of their prescribed duties, as the yajñeśvara; and those who are yogīs seeking mystic powers are awarded such powers. In other words, everyone is dependant for success upon His mercy alone, and all kinds of spiritual processes are but different degrees of success on the same path.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.14

statements.statement: The living entities are entangled in the fruitive results of material activities because of their propensity for lording it over material resources.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.15

statements.statement: Those who are full of dirty things can take to the line of Krsna consciousness for a gradual cleansing process, following the regulative principles of devotional service.
Those who are already cleansed of the impurities may continue to act in the same Krsna consciousness so that others may follow their exemplary activities and thereby be benefitted.

Foolish persons or neophytes in Krsna consciousness often want to retire from activities without having knowledge of Krşņa consciousness. Arjuna's desire to retire from activities on the battlefield was not approved by the Lord. One need only know how to act.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.16

statements.statement: To act in Krsna consciousness, one has to follow the leadership of authorized persons who are in a line of disciplic succession.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.17

statements.statement: To understand one's constitution position, one has to associate with authorities in Krsna consciousness and learn the secret from them; this is as good as learning from the Lord directly.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.18

statements.statement: The impersonalist ceases fruitive activities out of fear, so that the resultant action may not be a stumbling block on the path of self-realization, but the personalist knows rightly his position as the eternal servitor of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Therefore he engages himself in the activities of Krsna consciousness.

Those who are engaged himself in the activities of Krsna consciousness are known to be without desire for personal sense gratification. The sense of eternal servitorship to Krsna makes one immune to all sorts of reactionary elements of work.

ref: Translation Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.19

statements.statement: One is understood to be in full knowledge whose every act is devoid of desire for sense gratification.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.20

statements.statement: A Krsna conscious person acts out of pure love for the Supreme Personality of Godhead, and therefore he has no attraction for the results of the action. He is not even attached to his personal maintenance, for everything is left to Krsna. Nor is he anxious to secure things, nor to protect things already in his possession. He does his duty to his best ability and leaves everything to Krsna.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.21

statements.statement: A Kṛṣṇa conscious person does not expect good or bad results in his activities. His mind and intelligence are fully controlled.

He knows that he is part and parcel of the Supreme, and therefore the part played by him, as a part and parcel of the whole, is not his by choice but is chosen for him by the Supreme and is done only through His agency.
A Kṛṣṇa conscious person is always dovetailed with the supreme desire, for he has no desire for personal sense gratification.
A Kṛṣṇa conscious man maintains himself by his work just to remain fit for action in the transcendental loving service of the Lord.
A Kṛṣṇa conscious person, fully engaged in self-realization, has very little time to falsely possess any material object.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.22

statements.statement: A Kṛṣṇa conscious person does not make much endeavor even to maintain his body. He is satisfied with gains which are obtained of their own accord.
He neither begs nor borrows, but he labors honestly as far as is in his power, and is satisfied with whatever is obtained by his own honest labor.
He does not allow anyone's service to hamper his own service in Kṛṣṇa consciousness.
For the service of the Lord he can participate in any kind of action without being disturbed by the duality of the material world.
A Kṛṣṇa conscious person is above duality because he does not hesitate to act in any way for the satisfaction of Kṛṣṇa. Therefore he is steady both in success and in failure.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.23

statements.statement: Becoming fully Kṛṣṇa conscious, one is freed from all dualities and thus is free from the contaminations of the material modes.
He can become liberated because he knows his constitutional position in relationship with Kṛṣṇa; and thus his mind cannot be drawn from Kṛṣṇa consciousness.
Whatever he does, he does for Kṛṣṇa, who is the primeval Viṣṇu. Therefore, all his works are technically sacrifices because sacrifice involves satisfying the Supreme Person, Kṛṣṇa.
The resultant reactions to all such work certainly merge into transcendence, and one does not suffer material effects.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.24

statements.statement: A conditioned soul, entangled in material contamination, is sure to act in the material atmosphere, and yet he has to get out of such an environment.
The more the activities of the material world are performed in Kṛṣṇa consciousness, or for Viṣṇu only, the more the atmosphere becomes spiritualized by complete absorption.
Everything that exists is situated in that brahmajyoti, but when the jyoti is covered by illusion (māyā) or sense gratification, it is called material.
The Absolute Truth covered by māyā is called matter.
Matter dovetailed for the cause of the Absolute Truth regains its spiritual quality.
Kṛṣṇa consciousness is the process of converting the illusory consciousness into Brahman, or the Supreme.
When the mind is fully absorbed in Kṛṣṇa consciousness, it is said to be in samādhi, or trance. Anything done in such transcendental consciousness is called yajña, or sacrifice for the Absolute.

In that condition of spiritual consciousness, the Contributor, the contribution, the consumption, the performer or leader of the performance, and the result or ultimate gain—everything—becomes one in the Absolute, the Supreme Brahman. That is the method of Kṛṣṇa consciousness.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.25

statements.statement: Factual sacrifice means to satisfy the Supreme Lord, Viṣṇu, who is also known as Yajñā.
The demigods are powerful living entities appointed by the Supreme Lord for the maintenance and supervision of all material functions like the heating, watering, and lighting of the universe.
Those who are interested in material benefits worship the demigods by various sacrifices according to the Vedic. They are called bahv-īśvara-vādī, or believers in many gods.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.26

statements.statement: A brahmacārī hears only words concerning Kṛṣṇa consciousness; hearing is the basic principle for understanding, and therefore the pure brahmacārī engages fully in harer nāmānukīrtanam—chanting and hearing the glories of the Lord.
Restricted, unattached sex life is also a kind of yajña because the restricted householder sacrifices his general tendency toward sense gratification for higher transcendental life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.29

statements.statement: Reducing the eating process is very helpful in the matter of sense control. And without sense control there is no possibility of getting out of the material entanglement.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.30

statements.statement: Sense gratification is the root cause of material existence; therefore, unless and until one is situated on a platform apart from sense gratification, there is no chance of being elevated to the eternal platform of full knowledge, full bliss and full life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.31

statements.statement: The highest perfection of liberated life is to associate with the supreme lord.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.33

statements.statement: There is a mystery about all different activities of sacrifice, and one should know this mystery.

Sacrifices sometimes take different forms according to the particular faith of the performer. When one's faith reaches the stage of transcendental knowledge, the performer of sacrifices should be considered more advanced than those who simply sacrifice material possessions without such knowledge, for without attainment of knowledge, sacrifices remain on the material platform and bestow no spiritual benefit.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.34

statements.statement: The Bhāgavatam says: dharmam hi sākṣād-bhagavat-pranītam—the path of religion is directly enunciated by the Lord.
Therefore, mental speculation or dry arguments cannot help one progress in spiritual life. One has to approach a bona fide spiritual master to receive the knowledge.
Such a spiritual master should be accepted in full surrender, and one should serve the spiritual master like a menial servant, without false prestige.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.35

statements.statement: Satisfaction of the self-realized spiritual master is the secret of advancement in spiritual life.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.36

statements.statement: The Māyāvādī philosophers wrongly think that Kṛṣṇa loses His own separate existence in His many expansions. This thought is material in nature.
Although we are separated parts of Kṛṣṇa, we are nevertheless not different from Him. The bodily difference of the living entities is māyā, or not actual fact.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 4.42

statements.statement: Ignorance can be removed by gradual acceptance of the principles of Kṛṣṇa consciousness.
A bona fide spiritual master is in the disciplic succession from time eternal.
Beware of self-interested people after personal aggrandizement who deviate others from the actual path.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.2

statements.statement: People are mad after sense gratification, and they do not know that this present body, which is full of miseries, is a result of one's fruitive activities in the past.
Although this body is temporary, it is always giving one trouble in many ways. Therefore, to act for sense gratification is not good.
Although the mind may be engrossed in fruitive activities and influenced by ignorance, one must develop a love for devotional service to Vasudeva.
Activities performed in full knowledge strengthen one's advancement in real knowledge.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.5

statements.statement: In the first process of sāṅkhya, one has to become detached from matter, and in the devotional yoga process one has to attach himself to the work of Kṛṣṇa.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.6

statements.statement: The Māyāvādī sannyāsīs also study the Vedānta-sūtras, but use their own commentary, called Śārīraka-bhāṣya, written by Śaṅkarācārya.
Because their studies become very tedious, they sometimes become tired of Brahman speculation, and thus they take shelter of the Bhāgavatam without proper understanding.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.7

statements.statement: One who works in Kṛṣṇa consciousness is servant to all, he is very dear to everyone. And, because everyone is satisfied by his work, he is pure in consciousness. Because he is pure in consciousness, his mind is completely controlled. And, because his mind is controlled, his senses are also controlled.

There is not a chance, whose mind always fixed on Kṛṣṇa will engage his senses in matters other than the service of the Lord. He does not like to hear anything except topics relating to Kṛṣṇa, he does not like to eat anything which is not offered to Kṛṣṇa, and he does not wish to go anywhere if Kṛṣṇa is not involved. Therefore, his senses are controlled.
A man of controlled senses can't be offensive to anyone.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.8-9

statements.statement: A person in Kṛṣṇa consciousness is pure in his existence, and consequently he has nothing to do with any work which depends upon five immediate and remote causes: the doer, the work, the situation, the endeavor and fortune. This is because he is engaged in the loving transcendental service of Kṛṣṇa. Although he appears to be acting with his body and senses, he is always conscious of his actual position, which is spiritual engagement.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.10

statements.statement: One who knows perfectly well that everything belongs to Kṛṣṇa, that He is the proprietor of everything and that, therefore, everything is engaged in the service of the Lord, naturally has nothing to do with the results of his activities, whether virtuous or sinful. Even one's material body, being a gift of the Lord for carrying out a particular type of action, can be engaged in Kṛṣṇa consciousness. He is beyond contamination by sinful reactions, exactly as the lotus leaf, though remaining in the water, is not wet.

ref: Translation Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.12

statements.statement: The steadily devoted soul attains unadulterated peace because he offers the result of all activities to Me; whereas a person who is not in union with the Divine, who is greedy for the fruits of his labor, becomes entangled.

ref: Purport Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.13

statements.statement: The embodied soul lives in the city of nine gates. The activities of the body, or the figurative city of body, are conducted automatically by the particular modes of nature. The soul, although subjecting himself to the conditions of the body, can be beyond those conditions, if he so desires. Owing only to forgetfulness of his superior nature, he identifies with the material body, and therefore suffers.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.16

statements.statement: The spiritual master can drive away all nescience, as the sun drives away darkness. Even though a person may be in full knowledge that he is not this body but is transcendental to the body, he still may not be able to discriminate between the soul and the Supersoul. However, he can know everything well if he cares to take shelter of the perfect, bona fide Krşņa conscious spiritual master.

One can know God and one's relationship with God only when one actually meets a representative of God. A representative of God never claims that he is God, although he is paid all the respect ordinarily paid to God because he has knowledge of God.
At night we see everything as one in the darkness, but in day when the sun is up, we see everything in its real identity. Identity with individuality in spiritual life is real knowledge.

ref: Translation by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.17

statements.statement: When one's intelligence, mind, faith and refuge are all fixed in the Supreme, then one becomes fully cleansed of misgivings through complete knowledge and thus proceeds straight on the path of liberation.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.18

statements.statement: The bodies are material productions of different modes of material nature.

ref: Translation by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.19

statements.statement: Those whose minds are established in sameness and equanimity have already conquered the conditions of birth and death.
The lord is flawless because he is without attraction or hatred, similarly, when a living entity is without attraction or hatred, he also becomes flawless and eligible to enter into spiritual sky.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.20

statements.statement: The first symptom of self-realised person is that he is not illusioned by the false identification of the body with his true self. He knows perfectly well that he is not this body, but is the fragmental portion of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. He is therefore not joyful in achieving something, nor does he lament in losing anything which is related to his body. This steadiness of mind is called sthira-buddhi, or self-intelligence.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.21

statements.statement: The highest pleasure in terms of matter is sex pleasure. The whole world is moving under its spell, and a materialist cannot work at all without this motivation.
Spiritual realization and sex pleasure go ill together.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.22

statements.statement: Those who are true yogis or learned transcendentalists are not attracted by sense pleasures, which are the causes of continuous material existence. The more one is addicted to material pleasures, the more he is entrapped by material miseries.

ref: Translation by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.23

statements.statement: Before giving up this present body, if one is able to tolerate the urges of the material senses and check the force of desire and anger, he is a yogi and is happy in this world.

Material desires, when unsatiated, generate anger and thus the mind, eyes and chest become agitated. Therefore, one must practice to control them before one gives up this material is thus happy in the state of self-realization.
It is the duty of the transcendentalist to try strenuously to control desire and anger.

ref: Translation by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.24

statements.statement: One whose happiness is within, who is active within, who rejoices within and is illumined within, is actually the perfect mystic.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.24

statements.statement: A liberated person who enjoys happiness by factual experience, no longer desires external material happiness. He can, therefore, sit silently at any place and enjoy the activities of life from within. This state is called brahma-bhūta, attaining which one is assured of going back to Godhead, back to home.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.25

statements.statement: Only a person who is fully in Krsna consciousness can be said to be engaged in welfare work for all living entities. When a person is actually in the knowledge that Krsna is the fountain head of everything, then when he acts in that spirit he acts for everyone.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.26

statements.statement: In the conditioned soul the desire to enjoy the fruitive results of work is so deep-rooted that it is very difficult even for the great sages to control such desires, despite great endeavors.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 5.29

statements.statement: Under the spell of illusion, living entities are trying to be lords of all they survey, but actually they are dominated by the material energy of the Lord. The Lord is the master of material nature, and the conditioned souls are under the stringent rules of material nature. Unless one understands these bare facts, it is not possible to achieve peace in the world either individually or collectively. This is the sense of Krsna consciousness: Lord Krşņa is the supreme predominator, and all living entities, including the great demigods, are His subordinates.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.1

statements.statement: A Kṛṣṇa conscious person has no desire for self-satisfaction. His criterion of success is the satisfaction of Kṛṣṇa, and thus he is the perfect sannyāsī, or perfect yogi.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.2

statements.statement: A person in Kṛṣṇa consciousness has no opportunity to engage his senses in anything which is not for the purpose of Kṛṣṇa.
If one is unable to give up the activities of his selfish nature, then jñāna and yoga are of no avail.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.4

statements.statement: When a person is fully engaged in the transcendental loving service of the Lord, he is pleased in himself, and thus he is no longer engaged in sense gratification or in fruitive activities.
Without Kṛṣṇa consciousness, one must be always seeking self-centered or extended selfish activities.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.5

statements.statement: The pure soul is entangled in the material world because of the mind's ego which desires to lord it over material nature. Therefore, the mind should be trained so that it will not be attracted by the glitter of material nature.
The best way to disentangle oneself is to always engage the mind in Kṛṣṇa consciousness.

ref: Purport by Viswa Guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.6

statements.statement: The purpose of practicing eightfold yoga is to control the mind in order to make it a friend in discharging the human mission. Unless the mind is controlled, the practice of yoga (for show) is simply a waste of time.
One who cannot control his mind lives always with the greatest enemy, and thus his life and its mission are spoiled.

The constitutional position of the living entity is to carry out the order of the superior. As long as one's mind remains an unconquered enemy, one has to serve the dictations of lust, anger, avarice, illusion, etc. But when the mind is conquered, one voluntarily agrees to abide by the dictation of the Personality of Godhead, who is situated within the heart of everyone as Paramātmā.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.8

statements.statement: Book knowledge without realisation of Supreme Truth is useless.
A Krsna conscious person has realized knowledge, by the grace of Krsna, because he is satisfied with pure devotional service.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.10

statements.statement: The first business of a transcendentalist is to keep the mind always on Krsna.
One should always think of Krsna and not forget Him even for a moment.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.13–14

statements.statement: Vigatabhih. One cannot be fearless unless one is fully in Krsna consciousness. A conditioned soul is fearful due to his perverted memory, his forgetfulness of his eternal relationship with Krsna.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.15

statements.statement: One who seeks an improvement in health or aspires after material perfection is no yogi according to Bhagavad-gītā. Nor does cessation of material existence entail one's entering into "the void," which is only a myth, There is no void anywhere within the creation of the Lord.
No one can reach the spiritual sky or enter into the eternal abode (Vaikuntha Goloka Vrndāvana) of the Lord without the proper understanding of Krsna and His plenary expansion Vişnu.
Perfection of the yoga system is the attainment of freedom from material existence and not some magical jugglery or gymnastic feats to befool innocent people.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.16

statements.statement: One who eats sin and eats more than is allotted to him cannot execute perfect yoga.
One who eats more than required will dream very much while sleeping, and he must consequently sleep more than is required.

ref: Translation – Bhagavad-gītā 6.17

statements.statement: He who is temperate in his habits of eating, sleeping, working and recreation can mitigate all material pains by practicing the yoga system.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.17

statements.statement: Extravagance in the matter of eating, sleeping, defending and mating-which are demands of the body-can block advancement in the practice of yoga.

As far as sleeping is concerned, a Krsna conscious person is always alert in the discharge of his duties in Krsna consciousness, and therefore any unnecessary time spent sleeping is considered a great loss. A Krsna conscious person cannot bear to pass a minute of his life without being engaged in the service of the Lord. Therefore, his sleeping is kept to a minimum. His ideal in this respect is Srila Rūpa Gosvāmī, who was always engaged in the service of Krsna and who could not sleep more than two hours a day, and sometimes not even that.
Thakura Haridāsa would not even accept prasādam nor even sleep for a moment without finishing his daily routine of chanting with his beads three hundred thousand names.
As far as work is concerned, a Krsna conscious person does not do anything which is not connected with Krsna's interest.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.18

statements.statement: The activities of the yogi are distinguished from those of an ordinary person by his characteristic cessation from all kinds of material desires of which sex is the chief.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.20–23

statements.statement: One has to meet the demands of the body, namely eating, sleeping, defending and mating. But a person who is in pure bhakti-yoga or in Krsna consciousness does not arouse the senses while meeting the demands of the body. Rather, he accepts the bare necessities of life, making the best use of a bad bargain, and enjoys transcendental happiness in Krsna consciousness. He is callous toward incidental occurrences—such as accidents, disease, scarcity and even the death of a most dear relative—but he is always alert to execute his duties in Krsna consciousness or bhakti-yoga. Accidents never deviate him from his duty.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.24

statements.statement: The yoga practitioner should be determined and should patiently prosecute the practice without deviation. One should be sure of success at the end and pursue this course with great perserverance, not becoming discouraged if there is any delay in the attainment of success. Success is sure for the rigid practitioner.

The process of bhakti-yoga can be executed successfully with full-hearted enthusiasm, perseverance, and determination by following the prescribed duties in the association of devotees and by engaging completely in activities of goodness.

The practice of yoga, especially bhakti-yoga in Krsna consciousness, may appear to be a very difficult job. But if anyone follows the principles with great determination, the Lord will surely help, for God helps those who help themselves.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.25

statements.statement: By proper conviction and intelligence one should gradually cease sense activities. This is called pratyāhāra. The mind, being controlled by conviction, meditation, and cessation of the senses, should be situated in trance, or samādhi.

Although one is involved with matter as long as the material body exists, one should not think about sense gratification. One should think of no pleasure aside from the pleasure of the Supreme Self. This state is easily attained by directly practicing Krşņa consciousness.

ref: Translation – Bhagavad-gītā 6.27

statements.statement: The yogi whose mind is fixed on Me verily attains the highest happiness. By virtue of his identity with Brahman, he is liberated; his mind is peaceful, his passions are quieted, and he is freed from sin.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.27

statements.statement: One cannot remain in the quality of Brahman, the Absolute, until one's mind is fixed on the lotus feet of the Lord.

Sa vai manaḥ kṛṣṇa-padāravindayoh. To be always engaged in the transcendental loving service of the Lord, or to remain in Krsna consciousness, is to be factually liberated from the mode of passion and all material contamination.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.28

statements.statement: Self-realization means knowing one's constitutional position in relationship to the Supreme. The individual soul is part and parcel of the Supreme, and his position is to render transcendental service to the Lord. This transcendental contact with the Supreme is called brahma-samsparśa.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.29

statements.statement: The perfect yogi knows that the Lord is eternally transcendental and is not materially affected by His presence in either a dog or a brāhmana.

The Lord, being the source of all beings, is like the mother and the maintainer. As the mother is neutral to all different kinds of children, the Supreme Father (or Mother) is also. Consequently the Supersoul is always in every living being. Outwardly, also, every living being is situated in the energy of the Lord.

The Lord has, primarily, two energies—the spiritual (or superior) and the material (or inferior). The living entity, although part of the superior energy, is conditioned by the inferior energy; the living entity is always in the Lord's energy. Every living entity is situated in Him in one way or another.
While in the material energy, the living entity serves the material senses; and while in spiritual energy, he serves the Supreme Lord directly.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.32

statements.statement: One who is Krsna conscious is a perfect yogi; he is aware of everyone's happiness and distress by dint of his own personal experience.

The cause of the distress of a living entity is forgetfulness of his relationship with God. And the cause of happiness is knowing Krsna to be the supreme enjoyer of all the activities of the human being. Krsna is the proprietor of all lands and planets.
The perfect yogi is the sincerest friend of all living entities.
Because one in Krsna consciousness is happy, he tries to distribute the knowledge of Krsna everywhere.

A devotee of the Lord always looks to the welfare of all living entities, and in this way he is factually the friend of everyone. He is the best yogi because he does not desire perfection in yoga for his personal benefit, but tries for others also. He does not envy his fellow living entities. Here is a contrast with a yogi interested only in his personal elevation.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.34

statements.statement: The mind is so strong and obstinate that it sometimes overcomes the intelligence, although mind is supposed to be subservient to the intelligence.
Artificially, one may establish a mental equilibrium toward both friend and enemy, but ultimately no worldly man can do so, for this is more difficult than controlling the raging wind.
Intelligence is supposed to direct the mind, but the mind is understood by great is so strong and obstinate that it often overcomes even one's own Intelligence.
The easiest way to control the mind, as suggested by Lord Caitanya, is chanting "Hare Krsna," the great mantra for deliverance, in all humility.

ref: Translation – Bhagavad-gītā 6.35

statements.statement: The Blessed Lord said: O mighty-armed son of Kunti, it is undoubtedly very difficult to curb the restless mind, but it is possible by constant practice and by detachment.

ref: Purport by Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā 6.35

statements.statement: The first and foremost devotional engagement is hearing about Krsna. This is a very powerful transcendental method for purging the mind of all misgivings. The more one hears about Krsna, the more one becomes enlightened and detached from everything that draws the mind away from Krsna.

Hearing of the transcendental activities of Lord Krsna is expert treatment for the mad mind, and eating the foodstuff offered to Krsna is the appropriate diet for the suffering patient. This treatment is the process of Krsna consciousness.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.36

statements.statement: A Krsna conscious person easily achieves the result of yoga practice without separate endeavor, but a yoga practitioner cannot achieve success without becoming Krsna conscious.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.37

statements.statement: Even a little endeavor on the transcendental path offers a great hope for deliverance.
To pursue the transcendental path is more or less to declare war on illusory energy.

A conditioned soul is already allured by the modes of material energy, and there is every chance of being allured again, even while performing transcendental disciplines. This is called yogat calita-mānasah: deviation from the transcendental path.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.38

statements.statement: When one takes to the path of Transcendence, one has to cease all material activities and sacrifice all forms of so-called material happiness.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.39

statements.statement: Krsna and Krsna conscious devotees alone can know what is what.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.40

statements.statement: A transcendentalist is supposed to give up all material activities for the sake of spiritual advancement in life, Krsna consciousness.
Any activity which is not aimed at ultimate self-realization or liberation from the material bodily concept of life is not at all auspicious.
Anyone who voluntarily accepts all bodily discomforts for the sake of making progress on the path of Krsna consciousness can be called a perfect transcendentalist under severe austerity.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 6.47

statements.statement: The yogi who is progressive is therefore on the true path of eternal good fortune.
Bhakti means devotional service to the Lord which is free from desire for material profit, either in this life or in the next.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.1

statements.statement: One should therefore begin yoga practice by Concentration of the mind upon Krsna. The Supreme is made possible by prescribed devotional service in nine different forms, of which śravanam is the first and most important. The Lord therefore says to Arjuna, 'tat śrnu,' or 'Hear from Me.' No one can be a greater authority than Krsna, and therefore by hearing from Him one receives the greatest opportunity for progress in Krsna consciousness. One has therefore to learn from Krşņa directly or from a pure devotee of Krsna-and not from a nondevotee upstart, puffed up with academic education.
To hear about Krsna from Vedic literatures, or to hear from Him directly through the Bhagavad-gītā, is itself righteous activity.
One who hears about Krsna, Lord Krsna, who is dwelling in everyone's heart, acts as a best-wishing friend and purifies the devotee who constantly engages in hearing of Him.

A devotee naturally develops his dormant transcendental knowledge. As he hears more about Krsna from the Bhāgavatam and from the devotees, he becomes fixed in the devotional service of the Lord. By development of devotional service one becomes freed from the modes of passion and ignorance, and thus material lusts and avarice are diminished. When these impurities are wiped away, the candidate remains steady in his position of pure goodness becomes enlivened by devotional service and understands the science of God perfectly.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.2

statements.statement: Complete knowledge includes knowledge of the phenomenal world and the spirit behind it. The source of both of them is transcendental knowledge.
When the cause of all causes becomes known, then everything knowable becomes known, and nothing remains unknown. The Vedas say, 'yasmin vijñāte sarvam eva vijñatam bhavanti.'

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.3

statements.statement: The first 6 chapters of gita are meant for those who are interested in transcendental knowledge, in understanding the self, the Superself and the process of realization by jñāna-yoga, dhyana-yoga, and discrimination of the self from matter.
The yogīs and jñānīs are confused in their attempts to understand Krsna.
The greatest of the impersonalists, Śrīpāda Śańkarācārya, has admitted in his Gītā commentary that Krsna is the Supreme Personality of Godhead.

Actually the path of bhakti is not easy. The so-called path of bhakti practiced by unauthorized persons without knowledge of bhakti may be easy, but when it is practiced factually according to the rules and regulations, the speculative scholars and philosophers fall away from the path.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.4

statements.statement: All the activities of the material world are directed by these three Vişnu expansions of Lord Krsna.
There are no spiritual diversities in brahmajyoti as there are in the Vaikunthalokas, and the impersonalist accepts this brahmajyoti as the ultimate eternal goal.
The Paramātmā manifestation is also a temporary all-pervasive aspect of the Kşīrodakaśāyī Vişnu. The Paramātmā manifestation is not eternal in the spiritual world.

In the material energy, the principal manifestations are eight. Out of these, the first five manifestations, namely earth, water, fire, air and sky, are called the five gigantic creations or the gross creations, within which the five sense objects are included.
The false ego 'I am,' and 'It is mine,' which constitute the basic principle of material existence includes ten sense organs for material activities.
Sense object are the manifestations of physical sound, touch, form, taste and smell.
Intelligence refers to the total material creation, called the mahat-tattva.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.5

statements.statement: Energies are always controlled by the energetic.

If the living entities are accepted as minute energies of Lordship, then they are at once subject to supreme control. Therefore real liberation entails surrender by the living entities to Lord's control, and that surrender will make them happy. In that constitutional position only can they be controllers.

While exploiting the gross and subtle inferior energy (matter), the superior energy (the living entity) forgets his real spiritual mind and intelligence. This forgetfulness is due to the influence of matter upon the living entity.

The false ego, under the influence of material illusion, thinks, 'I am matter, and material acquisitions are mine.' His actual position is realized when he is liberated from all material ideas, including the conception of his becoming one in all respects with God.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.6

statements.statement: Spirit is the basic field of creation.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.8

statements.statement: Practically speaking, there is no conflict between personalism and impersonalism. One who knows God knows that the impersonal conception and personal conception are simultaneously present in everything and that there is no contradiction. Therefore Lord Caitanya established His sublime doctrine: acintya-bheda and abheda-tattvam-simultaneously one and different.

The jurisdiction of Krsna consciousness extends everywhere, and one who knows Krsna consciousness is blessed. Those who do not know Krsna are in illusion, and so knowledge of Krsna is liberation, and ignorance of Him is bondage.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.9

statements.statement: In Krşņa consciousness we become aware that earth, water, fire, air and every active principle, all chemicals and all material elements are due to Krşņa. The duration of man's life is also due to Krşņa. Therefore by the grace of Krşņa, man can prolong his life or diminish it. So Krşņa consciousness is active in every sphere.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.10

statements.statement: Every entity is contained within the scope of 8,400,000 species of life.
Unless a person is intelligent he cannot understand the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Krsna.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.14

statements.statement: The conditioned soul is therefore called nitya-baddha, or eternally conditioned. No one can trace out the history of his becoming conditioned at a certain date in material history.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.15

statements.statement: Those who are not actually philosophers, scientists, educators, administrators, etc., but who pose themselves as such for material gain, do not accept the plan or path of the Supreme Lord. They have no idea of God; they simply manufacture their own worldly plans and consequently complicate the problems of material existence in their vain attempts to solve them. Because material energy (nature) is so powerful, it can resist the unauthorized plans of the atheists and baffle the knowledge of 'planning commissions.'

Material energy works fully under the direction of the Supreme Lord. It has no independent authority. It works as the shadow moves, in accordance with the movements of the object. But still material energy is very powerful, and the atheist, due to his godless temperament, cannot know how it works; nor can he know the plan of the Supreme Lord. Under illusion and the modes of passion and ignorance, all his plans are baffled, as in the case of Hiranyakaśipu and Rāvana, whose plans were smashed to dust although they were both materially learned as scientists, philosophers, administrators and educators.

Duşkrtinas, or miscreants, are of four different patterns: müdhas (grossly foolish persons), narādhama (the lowest of mankind), māyayāpahrta-jñāna (the deluded speculators), āsuraṁ bhāvam āśrita (the professed atheists).

The müdhas are those who are grossly foolish, like hard-working beasts of burden. They want to enjoy the fruits of their labor by themselves, and so do not want to part with them for the Supreme. The typical example of the beast of burden is the ass. This humble beast is made to work very hard by his master. The ass does not really know for whom he works so hard day and night. He remains satisfied by filling his stomach with a bundle of grass, sleeping for a while under fear of being beaten by his master, and satisfying his sex appetite at the risk of being repeatedly kicked by the opposite party. The ass sings poetry and philosophy sometimes, but this braying only disturbs others. This is the position of the foolish fruitive worker who does not know for whom he should work. He does not know that karma (action) is meant for yajña (sacrifice).

Those who work very hard day and night to clear the burden of self-created duties say that they have no time to hear of the immortality of the living being. To such müdhas, material gains, which are destructible, are life's all in all-despite the fact that the müdhas enjoy only a very small fraction of the fruit of labor. Sometimes they spend sleepless days and nights for fruitive gain, and although they may have ulcers or indigestion, they are satisfied with practically no food; they are simply absorbed in working hard day and night for the benefit of illusory masters. Ignorant of their real master, the foolish workers waste their valuable time serving mammon. Unfortunately, they never surrender to the supreme master of all masters.

Narādhama, or the lowest of mankind. Nara means human being, and adhama means the lowest. Out of the 8,400,000 different species of living beings, there are 400,000 human species. Out of these there are numerous lower forms of human life that are mostly uncivilized.
The purpose of following religious principles is to know the Supreme Truth and man's relation with Him.
99.9% of the population is narādhama.
The lowest amongst human beings can be delivered by submissive hearing, the message of the Personality of Godhead. Hearing process only.

Māyayāpahrta-jñāna, or those persons whose erudite knowledge has been nullified by the influence of illusory material energy. They are mostly very learned fellows-great philosophers, poets, literati, scientists, etc.-but the illusory energy misguides them, and therefore they disobey the Supreme Lord.
The blessed form of human life is designed after the eternal and transcendental feature of the Supreme Lord.

Āsuraṁ bhāvam āśrita, or those of demonic principles. This class is openly atheistic. Some of them argue that the Supreme Lord can never descend upon this material world, but they are unable to give any tangible reasons as to why not. There are others who make Him subordinate to the impersonal feature, although the opposite is declared in the Gitā.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.16

statements.statement: Pure devotional service is without aspiration and without desire for material profit.

When these four kinds of duşkrtinas, or miscreants persons come to the Supreme Lord for devotional service and are completely purified by the association of a pure devotee, they also become pure devotees.

The miscreants are concerned, for them devotional service is very difficult because their lives are selfish, irregular and without spiritual goals. But even some of them, by chance, when they come in contact with a pure devotee, also become pure devotees.

When the distressed, the inquisitive, the seekers of knowledge, and those who are in need of money are free from all material desires, and when they fully understand that material remuneration has nothing to do with spiritual improvement, they become pure devotees.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.17

statements.statement: He who is in knowledge of the Absolute Truth and free from all material desires becomes a really pure devotee of the Lord.

Out of the distressed, the inquisitive, the penniless, and the seeker after supreme knowledge, the devotee who is in full knowledge and is at the same time engaged in devotional service is, the Lord says, the best.

By searching after knowledge one realizes that his self is different from his material body, and when further advanced he comes to the knowledge of impersonal Brahman and Paramātmā. When one is fully purified, he realizes that his constitutional position is to be the eternal servant of God just by association with pure devotees.

In the preparatory stage, the man who is in full knowledge of the Supreme Lord and is at the same time executing devotional service is very dear to the Lord. He who is situated in pure knowledge of the transcendence of the Supreme Personality of God is so protected in devotional service that material contaminations cannot touch him.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.20

statements.statement: Even those who have material desires and who resort to the Supreme Lord are not so much attracted by external nature; because of approaching the right goal, they soon become free from all material lust.

It is said in the Bhagavatam that less intelligent people who have lost their spiritual sense take shelter of demigods for immediate fulfillment of material desires. Generally, such people do not go to the Supreme Personality of Godhead, because they are in particular modes of nature (ignorance and passion) and therefore worship various demigods.

In Vedic literature there are recommendations for worshiping different gods for different purposes (e.g., a diseased man is recommended to worship the sun), those who are not devotees of the Lord think that for certain purposes demigods are better than the Supreme Lord. But a pure devotee knows that the Supreme Lord Krsna is the master of all.
A pure devotee never goes to demigods for satisfaction of his material needs. He depends on the Supreme Lord. And the pure devotee is satisfied with whatever He gives.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.21

statements.statement: Some may ask why the all-powerful God gives facilities to the living entities for enjoying this material world and so lets them fall into the trap of the illusory energy. The answer is that if the Supreme Lord as Supersoul does not give such facilities, then there is no meaning to independence. Therefore He gives everyone full independence - whatever one likes - but His ultimate instruction we find in the Bhagavad-gītā: man should give up all other engagements and fully surrender unto Him. That will make man happy.
The living entity cannot worship the demigod by his own desire, nor can the demigod bestow any benediction without the supreme will.
The particular mode of the devotional attitude of the living entity toward a particular type of demigod is also arranged by the Supreme Lord.

The demigods cannot infuse the living entities with such an affinity, but because He is the Supreme Lord or the Supersoul who is present in the heart of all living entities, Krsna gives impetus to man to worship certain demigods.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.22

statements.statement: Asking for material benefit is not a sign of a pure devotee.

A living entity goes to the demigods usually because he is mad to fulfill his lust. This happens when something undue is desired by the living entity, and the Lord Himself does not fulfill the desire.
One who worships the Supreme Lord and at the same time desires material enjoyment is contradictory in his desires.

Devotional service of the Supreme Lord and the worship of a demigod cannot be on the same platform because worship of a demigod is material and devotional service to the Supreme Lord is completely spiritual.

For the living entity who desires to return to Godhead, material desires are impediments. A pure devotee of the Lord is therefore not awarded the material benefits desired by less intelligent living entities who prefer to worship demigods of the material world rather than engage in devotional service of the Supreme Lord.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.23

statements.statement: Not only are demigods parts of the Supreme Lord, but ordinary living entities are also. In the Śrīmad-Bhagavatam it is stated that the brahmaņas are the head of the Supreme Lord, the ksatriyas are the arms, etc., and that all serve different functions. Regardless of the situation, if one knows that both the demigods and himself are part and parcel of the Supreme Lord, his knowledge is perfect. But if he does not understand this, he achieves different planets where the demigods reside. This is not the same destination the devotee reaches.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.24

statements.statement: Yāmunācārya, a great devotee of the Lord in the disciplic succession from Rāmānujācārya, says, 'My dear Lord, devotees like Vyāsadeva and Nārada know You to be the Personality of Godhead. By understanding different Vedic literatures, one can come to know Your characteristics, Your form and Your activities, and one can thus understand that You are the Supreme Personality of Godhead. But those who are in the modes of passion and ignorance, the demons, the nondevotees, cannot understand You.'
Persons who are under the impression that the Absolute Truth is impersonal are described as asuras, which means one who does not know the ultimate feature of the Absolute Truth.
The fact is that no one can understand Krsna without rendering devotional service and without developing Krsna consciousness.

One cannot understand the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Krsna, or His form, quality or name simply by mental speculation or by discussing Vedic literature. One must understand Him by devotional service. When one is fully engaged in Krşņa consciousness, beginning by chanting the mahāmantra-Hare Krşņa, Hare Krşņa, Krsna Krsna, Hare Hare/Hare Rama, Hare Rama, Rāma Rāma, Hare Hare-then only can one understand the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
Nondevotee impersonalists think that Krsna has a body made of this material nature and that all His activities, His form and everything, are maya These impersonalists are known as Māyāvādī.
The Vedas also confirm that the Supreme Absolute Truth is anandamaya, or full of blissful pleasure, and that He is abhyāsāt, by nature the reservoir of unlimited auspicious qualities.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.25

statements.statement: When Krsna was present there were only Bhīşma, Pandavas and a few other people who could understand Him to be the Supreme Personality of Godhead.
The Supreme Personality of Godhead, Lord Krsna, is not only unborn, but He is avyaya, inexhaustible. His eternal form is bliss and knowledge, and His energies are all inexhaustible.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.26

statements.statement: Unless one is liberated from material contamination, he cannot know past, present and future.

The transcendental body of Śrī Kṛşņa is not perishable. He is just like the sun, and māyā is like the cloud. In the material world we can see that there is the sun and that there are clouds and different stars and planets. The clouds may cover all these in the sky temporarily, but this covering is only apparent to our limited vision. The sun, moon and stars are not actually covered.
Māyā cannot cover the Supreme Lord. By His internal potency He is not manifest to the less intelligent class of men.

Even if one is perfected by realization of impersonal Brahman or localized Paramātmā, he cannot possibly understand the Supreme Personality of Godhead, Śrī Kṛşņa, without being in Krsna consciousness.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.28

statements.statement: Those who are sinful, atheistic, foolish and deceitful, it is very difficult to transcend the duality of desire and hate.

Only those who have passed their lives in practicing the regulative principles of religion, who have acted piously and have conquered sinful reactions can accept devotional service and gradually rise to the pure knowledge of the Supreme Personality of Godhead. Then, gradually, they can meditate in trance on the Supreme Personality of Godhead. That is the process of being situated on the spiritual platform. This elevation is possible in Krsna consciousness in the association of pure devotees who can deliver one from delusion.
If one actually wants to be liberated he must render service to the devotees: but one who associates with materialistic people is on the path leading to the darkest region of existence.
Unless one is reinstated in his own constitutional position, it is not possible to understand the Supreme Personality or to be fully engaged in His transcendental loving service with determination.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 7.30

statements.statement: Persons acting in Krsna consciousness are never entirely deviated from the path of understanding the Supreme Personality of Godhead.

In the transcendental association of Krsna consciousness, one can understand how the Supreme Lord is the governing principle of the material manifestation and even of the demigods. Gradually, by such transcendental association, one becomes convinced of the Supreme Personality of Godhead Himself, and at the time of death such a Krsna conscious person can never forget Krsna.
The beginning of Krsna consciousness is association of persons who are Krsna conscious.

By gradual development of Krsna consciousness in good association, the living entity can understand that due to forgetfulness of Krsna he has become conditioned by the laws of material nature. He can also understand that this human form of life is an opportunity to regain Krsna consciousness and that it should be fully utilized to attain the causeless mercy of the Supreme Lord.

He who is actually elevated in Krsna consciousness does not care for the different processes. He simply directly engages himself in activities of Krsna consciousness and thereby factually attains his constitutional position as eternal servitor of Lord Krşņa. He takes pleasure in hearing and glorifying the Supreme Lord in pure devotional service. He is convinced that by doing so, all his objectives will be fulfilled. This determined faith is called drdha-vrata, and it is the beginning of bhakti-yoga or transcendental loving service. That is the verdict of all scriptures.
The Seventh Chapter of the Gītā is the substance of conviction.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.3

statements.statement: To attain material heavenly planets and enjoy their facilities, one sometimes performs sacrifices (yajña), but when his merit is exhausted, he returns to earth again in the form of a man.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.4

statements.statement: The Supersoul, a plenary representation of Lord Kṛṣṇa, is called the Paramātmā or adhiyajña and is situated in the heart.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.5

statements.statement: Remembrance of Kṛṣṇa is not possible for the impure soul who has not practiced Kṛṣṇa consciousness in devotional service.

One should chant the mahāmantra, Hare Kṛṣṇa, Hare Kṛṣṇa, Kṛṣṇa Kṛṣṇa, Hare Hare / Hare Rāma, Hare Rāma, Rāma Rāma, Hare Hare, incessantly, following in the footsteps of Lord Caitanya, being more tolerant than the tree, humbler than the grass and offering all respect to others without requiring respect in return. In such a way one will be able to depart from the body successfully remembering Kṛṣṇa and so attain the supreme goal.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.6

statements.statement: The cumulative effect of the thoughts and actions of one's life influences one's thoughts at the moment of death; therefore the actions of this life determine one's future state of being.
If one is transcendentally absorbed in Kṛṣṇa's service, then his next body will be transcendental (spiritual), not physical.
Chanting of Hare Kṛṣṇa is the best process for successfully changing one's state of being to transcendental life.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.8

statements.statement: One's memory of Kṛṣṇa is revived by chanting the mahāmantra, Hare Kṛṣṇa.

The caterpillar thinks of becoming a butterfly and so is transformed into a butterfly in the same life. Similarly, if we constantly think of Kṛṣṇa, it is certain that at the end of our lives we shall have the same bodily constitution as Kṛṣṇa.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.9

statements.statement: The living entity is one 10,000th part of the tip of a hair, but the Lord is so inconceivably small that He enters into the heart of this particle.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.10

statements.statement: Yoga-balena — without practice of yoga one cannot come to this transcendental state of being (the mind fixed in devotion on the Supreme Godhead) at the time of death.
One cannot suddenly remember the Supreme Lord at death unless he is practiced in some yoga system, especially the system of bhakti-yoga.

ref: Purport by Viśva-guru Śrīla Prabhupāda – Bhagavad-gītā Chapter 8.11
